description: From French lampon (“satire, mockery, ridicule”), built on French lampons (“let us drink — a popular refrain for scurrilous songs”), from lamper (“to quaff, to swig”).

entries.meaning: A written attack or other work ridiculing a person, group, or institution.
examples: To say truth, Ma'am, 'tis very vulgar to Print and as my little Productions are mostly Satires and Lampoons I find they circulate more by giving copies in confidence to the Friends of the Parties—

verbs.description: lampoon (third-person singular simple present lampoons, present participle lampooning, simple past and past participle lampooned)

entries.meaning: To satirize or poke fun at.
